item.title: Abiogenesis
item.description: a set of humorous aphorisms that describe how communication often fails or leads to misunderstanding. They are named after Osmo Wiio, a Finnish professor and politician, who formulated them in 1978.

item.title: anthroposemiotics
item.description: field of study dedicated to understanding how humans communicate The evolution of human communication took place over a long period of time from simple hand gestures to the use of spoken language

item.title: Campbell's Law
item.description: a social science principle that states that when a metric is used as a target or indicator of performance, it tends to lose its validity and distort the system it is supposed to measure.

item.title: mass communication
item.description: process of imparting and exchanging information through mass media to large population segments. It utilizes various forms of media as technology has made the dissemination of information more efficient.

item.title: streisand effect
item.description: The Streisand effect is a phenomenon in which attempts to hide, remove, or censor information can lead to the unintended consequence of increasing awareness of that information.

item.title: Argument to Moderation
item.description: logical fallacy that assumes that the truth is always a compromise between two opposite positions. It is also known as false compromise, argument from middle ground, or the golden mean fallacy.

item.title: Tragedy of Commons
item.description: situation where people use a shared resource (such as land, water, air, etc.) without considering the impact on others or the future.
